properties.Title: Snow Squall Watch In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Moderate snow squalls occurring tonight. Weak to moderate snow squall bands have developed over the southern Gulf of St. Lawrence and will gradually diminish through the night into Thursday morning, as a ridge of high pressure moves over the Maritimes. Travel under these bands may be hazardous at times due to snow, blowing snow, and strong westerly winds. ### Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots may become difficult to navigate due to accumulating snow. Snow squall watches are issued when conditions are favourable for the formation of bands of snow that could produce intense accumulating snow or near zero visibilities. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NSstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NSStorm.
Expires: 2019-11-14T17:59:49-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-11-14T02:11:49-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2189404722.2019
Area: Pictou County, Antigonish County, Inverness County - south of Mabou, Inverness County - Mabou and north, Victoria County
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Freezing Drizzle Advisory In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Freezing drizzle will end this afternoon. ### Freezing drizzle can produce thin, hard-to-detect layers of ice. Freezing drizzle advisories are issued when drizzle falling in sub-zero temperatures is expected to freeze on contact, and over time create icy surfaces. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather in British Columbia or Yukon, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or YTstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm or #YTStorm.
Expires: 2019-11-15T04:12:40-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-11-14T12:13:40-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1098408548.2019
Area: Kluane Lake
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Blowing Snow Advisory In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Poor visibility in snow and blowing snow is expected late this afternoon into early Friday morning. Strong westerly winds up to 70 km/h will develop this afternoon during the passage of a cold front. Fresh snow combined with winds will reduce visibility to near zero at times. Reduced visibility in blowing snow can also be expected Friday morning with northwesterly winds gusting to 70 km/h. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2019-11-15T02:21:32-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-11-14T10:22:32-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.4050658706.2019
Area: Fort Severn
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Snow Squall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Lake effect snow squalls will continue today into tonight. Lake effect flurries and local snow squalls expected to continue through most of today. Local snowfall amounts near 20 cm will be possible along with reduced visibility in heavy snow at times. Snow squalls may intensify later tonight into Friday morning and further significant snowfall accumulation is possible. ### Snow squalls cause weather conditions to vary considerably; changes from clear skies to heavy snow within just a few kilometres are common. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2019-11-14T16:17:18-00:00

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: More rain on the way for Friday night. Total rainfall amounts: 20 to 40 mm. Locations: southwestern Newfoundland. Remarks: Rainfall amounts with the upcoming system on Friday night are not expected to be as significant as what fell with the recent rainfall event. However, flooding from the previous system could make some areas sensitive to any rainfall over the next few days, especially if the higher end of the expected amounts are realized. At this time, it doesn't appear that rainfall warnings will be needed for this system but the public should monitor the forecasts leading up to Friday and take necessary precautions for the forecast rainfall. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2019-11-15T00:49:00-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-11-14T08:50:00-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.0406890689.2019

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snow and wind expected for the weekend. Total snowfall: possibly exceeding 20 cm. Maximum wind gusts: 80 to 100 km/h along the coast. Locations: Natuashish to Makkovik. Time span: Friday night until Saturday night. Remarks: Snowfall is forecast to begin Friday night and continue into Saturday night. Early Saturday, strong winds are expected to develop along the coast. Snow and blowing snow will combine to produce poor visibility in blowing snow. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2019-11-15T01:31:08-00:00

properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Blizzard Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Blizzard conditions with gusty winds and persistent visibility near zero in snow and blowing snow are expected or occurring. Blizzard conditions have developed and will intensify today. Wind gusts exceeding 100 km/h near the Richardson Mountains with falling snow will produce near zero visibility in blowing snow. Blizzard conditions will abate overnight as winds subside to 30 to 50 km/h. ### Road closures are likely. Blizzard warnings are issued when widespread reduced visibilities of 400 metres or less are expected for at least 4 hours. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather in British Columbia or Yukon, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or YTstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm or #YTStorm.
Expires: 2019-11-15T04:27:09-00:00

properties.Title: Snow Squall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Isolated lake effect snow squalls possible until the morning. Lake effect flurries are expected to continue. Some of these flurries are then expected to intensify into local snow squalls and continue into the morning. Areas south and east of Elliot Lake are most likely to see the snow squalls. Local snowfall accumulations of 10 to 20 cm will be possible by the time the snow squalls move east of the region in the morning. ### Snow squalls cause weather conditions to vary considerably; changes from clear skies to heavy snow within just a few kilometres are common. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2019-11-14T19:59:53-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-11-14T05:35:53-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.4093439186.2019
Area: Elliot Lake - Ranger Lake, Blind River - Thessalon
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Snow Squall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Lake effect snow squalls continue. Southwesterly winds over the relatively warm waters of Lake Superior are producing flurries and local snow squalls which will continue into the morning. The snow squalls are expected to shift south of Wawa in the morning. Local snowfall amounts of 10 to 15 cm are possible, however areas closer to Lake Superior could see locally higher amounts of 15 to 25 cm. Additional amounts of 5 to 15 cm are possible in the morning. Local blowing snow reducing visibilities can be expected. The local snow squalls are forecast to taper off when the winds become lighter and shift to the northwest later today. ### Snow squalls cause weather conditions to vary considerably; changes from clear skies to heavy snow within just a few kilometres are common. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2019-11-14T21:27:25-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-11-14T05:28:25-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3455455466.2019

properties.Title: Wind Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Strong winds that may cause damage are expected or occurring. Maximum gusts: 90 km/h, except 110 along parts of the coast. Locations: Nain and vicinity. Time span: tonight until Thursday morning. ### Damage to buildings, such as to roof shingles and windows, may occur. Loose objects may be tossed by the wind and cause injury or damage. Wind warnings are issued when there is a significant risk of damaging winds. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
